demographics.other: Peer mentor in the Engineering Learning Community

summaries.title: Developing Academic Confidence Through Mentorship
summaries.summaryText: Daniel described feeling initially out of place in rigorous electrical engineering courses, particularly when comparing himself to peers with prior robotics or coding experience. His confidence improved after joining a peer mentoring program where upperclassmen provided guidance and reassurance.

summaries.title: Family Support and Pressure as a Dual Motivation
summaries.summaryText: As a first-generation student, Daniel’s parents provided emotional encouragement but limited academic guidance. Their sacrifices motivated him, though he expressed anxiety about failing to meet expectations.

summaries.title: Balancing Pressure, Pride, and Belonging
summaries.summaryText: Daniel expressed pride in representing his family’s aspirations but also noted ongoing struggles with imposter syndrome. He values belonging through peer groups that normalize his experiences as a first-gen student of color in STEM.

timelinePoints.eventDescription: Struggled during his first programming course, leading him to seek help from tutoring and peers.
Joined the Engineering Learning Community, finding peer mentors and emotional support.
Presented a project on sustainable energy systems at an undergraduate research showcase.

themes.title: Imposter Syndrome Among First-Generation Asian-American Students
themes.description: Daniel’s experience illustrates how first-generation students often internalize academic challenges as personal shortcomings, especially when they lack peers with shared backgrounds in STEM programs.

themes.title: Peer Mentorship as a Belonging Intervention
themes.description: Daniel emphasized how structured mentorship programs provided psychological safety and belonging cues, normalizing struggle and improving persistence among marginalized students.

themes.title: Family Expectations and Cultural Motivation
themes.description: Cultural values around family honor and sacrifice serve both as motivation and a source of pressure for first-generation Vietnamese-American students pursuing STEM.

quotes.quoteText: My parents don’t really understand what I study, but they tell everyone I’m going to be an engineer — that means a lot, but it’s also scary.
quotes.context: Daniel reflecting on parental expectations and emotional weight of being first-gen.

quotes.quoteText: Sometimes I feel like everyone else just gets it — like I’m pretending to belong in these classes.
quotes.context: Daniel discussing his sense of imposter syndrome in engineering coursework.

quotes.quoteText: It took me a year to realize struggling is normal — not a sign that I’m not supposed to be here.
quotes.context: Daniel describing the turning point after joining peer mentoring programs.

quotes.quoteText: Having mentors who also came from immigrant families helped me feel like my story belonged here too.
quotes.context: Daniel describing peer mentorship as a belonging intervention.

quotes.quoteText: My parents say, ‘Just do your best,’ but I can tell they really mean, ‘Don’t waste this chance we gave you.’
quotes.context: Daniel reflecting on implicit cultural pressure from family expectations.

areasForImprovement.title: Expand Peer Mentoring for First-Generation STEM Students
areasForImprovement.description: Formalize mentoring programs that pair upperclassmen with first-generation students early in their academic journey. These networks reduce imposter syndrome and improve retention rates.
actionItems: Create opt-in mentoring tracks for first-gen students
Provide mentor training focused on inclusive communication

areasForImprovement.title: Normalize Academic Struggle Through Faculty Messaging
areasForImprovement.description: Faculty can help counter imposter syndrome by sharing personal learning experiences, highlighting that mastery develops over time and through mistakes.
actionItems: Encourage faculty to include ‘learning journeys’ in course introductions
Develop short workshops on inclusive teaching practices
